title: Modes of convergence (annotated index)
text:
The purpose of this article is to serve as an <a href="Annotation">annotated</a> <a href="Index%20%28publishing%29">index</a> of various modes of convergence and their logical relationships. For an expository article, see <a href="Modes%20of%20convergence">Modes of convergence</a>. Simple logical relationships between different modes of convergence are indicated (e.g., if one implies another), formulaically rather than in prose for quick reference, and indepth descriptions and discussions are reserved for their respective articles.
"Guide to this index." To avoid excessive verbiage, note that each of the following types of objects is a special case of types preceding it: <a href="set%20%28mathematics%29">set</a>s, <a href="topological%20space">topological space</a>s, <a href="uniform%20space">uniform space</a>s, <a href="topological%20abelian%20group">topological abelian group</a>s (TAG), <a href="normed%20vector%20space">normed vector space</a>s, <a href="Euclidean%20space">Euclidean space</a>s, and the <a href="Real%20number">real</a>/<a href="Complex%20number">complex</a> numbers. Also note that any <a href="metric%20space">metric space</a> is a uniform space. Finally, subheadings will always indicate special cases of their superheadings.
The following is a list of modes of convergence for:
A sequence of elements {"an"} in a topological space ("Y").
...in a uniform space ("U").
Implications:
  -   Convergence formula_1 Cauchy-convergence
  -   Cauchy-convergence and convergence of a subsequence together formula_1 convergence.
  -   "U" is called "complete" if Cauchy-convergence (for nets) formula_1 convergence.
Note: A sequence exhibiting Cauchy-convergence is called a "cauchy sequence" to emphasize that it may not be convergent.
A series of elements Σ"bk" in a TAG ("G").
Implications:
  -   Unconditional convergence formula_1 convergence (by definition).
...in a normed space ("N").
Implications:
  -   Absolute-convergence formula_1 Cauchy-convergence formula_1 absolute-convergence of some grouping1.
  -   Therefore: "N" is <a href="Banach%20space">Banach</a> (complete) if absolute-convergence formula_1 convergence.
  -   Absolute-convergence and convergence together formula_1 unconditional convergence.
  -   Unconditional convergence formula_10 absolute-convergence, even if "N" is Banach.
  -   If "N" is a Euclidean space, then unconditional convergence formula_11 absolute-convergence.
1 Note: "grouping" refers to a series obtained by grouping (but not reordering) terms of the original series. A grouping of a series thus corresponds to a subsequence of its partial sums.
A sequence of functions {"fn"} from a set ("S") to a topological space ("Y").
...from a set ("S") to a uniform space ("U").
Implications are cases of earlier ones, except:
  -   Uniform convergence formula_1 both pointwise convergence and uniform Cauchy-convergence.
  -   Uniform Cauchy-convergence and pointwise convergence of a subsequence formula_1 uniform convergence.
...from a topological space ("X") to a uniform space ("U").
For many "global" modes of convergence, there are corresponding notions of "a") "local" and "b") "compact" convergence, which are given by requiring convergence to occur "a") on some neighborhood of each point, or "b") on all compact subsets of "X". Examples:
Implications:
  -   "Global" modes of convergence imply the corresponding "local" and "compact" modes of convergence. E.g.:
      Uniform convergence formula_1 both local uniform convergence and compact (uniform) convergence.
  -   "Local" modes of convergence tend to imply "compact" modes of convergence. E.g.,
      Local uniform convergence formula_1 compact (uniform) convergence.
  -   If formula_16 is locally compact, the converses to such tend to hold:
      Local uniform convergence formula_11 compact (uniform) convergence.
...from a measure space (S,μ) to the complex numbers (C).
Implications:
  -   Pointwise convergence formula_1 almost everywhere convergence.
  -   Uniform convergence formula_1 almost uniform convergence.
  -   Almost everywhere convergence formula_1 convergence in measure. (In a finite measure space)
  -   Almost uniform convergence formula_1 convergence in measure.
  -   Lp convergence formula_1 convergence in measure.
  -   Convergence in measure formula_1 convergence in distribution if μ is a probability measure and the functions are integrable.
A series of functions Σ"gk" from a set ("S") to a TAG ("G").
Implications are all cases of earlier ones.
...from a set ("S") to a normed space ("N").
Generally, replacing "convergence" by "absolute-convergence" means one is referring to convergence of the series of nonnegative functions formula_24 in place of formula_25.
Implications are cases of earlier ones, except:
  -   Normal convergence formula_1 uniform absolute-convergence
...from a topological space ("X") to a TAG ("G").
Implications are all cases of earlier ones.
...from a topological space ("X") to a normed space ("N").
Implications (mostly cases of earlier ones):
  -   Uniform absolute-convergence formula_1 both local uniform absolute-convergence and compact (uniform) absolute-convergence.
      Normal convergence formula_1 both local normal convergence and compact normal convergence.
  -   Local normal convergence formula_1 local uniform absolute-convergence.
      Compact normal convergence formula_1 compact (uniform) absolute-convergence.
  -   Local uniform absolute-convergence formula_1 compact (uniform) absolute-convergence.
      Local normal convergence formula_1 compact normal convergence
  -   If "X" is locally compact:
      Local uniform absolute-convergence formula_11 compact (uniform) absolute-convergence.
      Local normal convergence formula_11 compact normal convergence
